'''Tar-Amandil''' was the third [[King of Númenor|King]] of [[Númenor]]. He ruled de-facto for 148 years, from 442 to 590 of the [[Second Age]]. Tar-Amandil was legally the third King, but actually its second ruler.<ref name=Tar-Amandil/> His father, [[Vardamir|Vardamir Nólimon]], declined to take the [[Sceptre]] upon the death of his own father, [[Elros|Elros Tar-Minyatur]], and was only a titular King that was deemed to have reigned one year.<ref name=Vardamir/>

Tar-Amandil had three children: two sons, [[Tar-Elendil|Elendil]] and [[Eärendur (son of Tar-Amandil)|Eärendur]]; and a daughter, [[Mairen]].<ref name=earlier/> Just as his father had yielded the Sceptre before his death, Tar-Amandil abdicated in 590<ref name=Tar-Amandil/> and was succeeded by his eldest son Elendil, who would rule as [[Tar-Elendil]].<ref name=earlier/> This tradition of renouncing the Sceptre a few years before death was observed by most of the rulers of Númenor until [[Tar-Atanamir]].<ref>{{UT|Kings}}, entry XIII ''Tar-Atanamir the Great''</ref>

== Etymology ==
''Amandil'' is [[Quenya]]. The name is glossed to mean "Lover of Aman".<ref>{{S|Index}}</ref> According to Paul Strack, the name is a compound of ''[[Aman]]'' ("Blessed Realm") and ''[[-ndil|-(n)dil]]'' ("friend, lover, devoted to").<ref>{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=https://www.eldamo.org/content/words/word-2943820837.html|articlename=Q. ''Amandil'' m.|website=Eldamo|accessed=12 December 2021}}</ref> Like all the rulers of Númenor who took their royal names in Quenya, Amandil added the prefix ''tar-'' ("high") to his name when he received the Sceptre.<ref>{{UT|Kings}}, first paragraph and entry I to XXV</ref>

The [[Adûnaic]] version of his name is '''''Aphanuzîr''''',<ref>{{SD|3iiic}}, p. 389</ref> which Paul Strack suggests probably means "Bliss-friend".<ref>{{webcite|author=Paul Strack|articleurl=http://eldamo.org/content/words/word-2313573009.html|articlename=Ad. ''Aphanuzîr'' m.|website=[http://eldamo.org/index.html Eldamo - An Elvish Lexicon]|accessed=5 October 2019}}</ref>

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In the twelfth note to a text written around [[1959]] and published in ''[[The Nature of Middle-earth]]'', it is said that either the slow maturity of the [[Half-elven]], or the "choice of kindred"<ref name=Nature>{{NM|P1xi}}</ref>{{rp|78}} extended to the third generation, suggesting that Tar-Amandil, and [[Eldarion]], were among the Half-elven.<ref name=Nature/>{{rp|82}} However, this was changed to the second generation in the actual text.<ref name=Nature/>{{rp|78}}
